field_reports.description:
On December 17, 2024, a powerful magnitude 7.3 earthquake struck near Vanuatu's capital, Port Vila, around 02:25 PM, leaving thousands of people in urgent need of aid. Immediate priorities include life-saving Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH) supplies, first aid, health services, and psychological support. A State of Emergency was declared on December 17, 2024, in the worst-affected areas of Vanuatu for a duration of seven days.

By December 18, the National Disaster Management Office (NDMO) confirmed 14 fatalities caused by collapsed buildings and landslides. The death toll could rise as search and rescue operations expand. Over 200 people have been injured, with many still missing. According to UNICEF staff on-site, injuries are primarily fractures, cuts, and trauma caused by falling debris. The Government of Vanuatu (GoV) estimates that over 80,000 people have been affected. Two major water reservoirs in Port Vila are severely damaged, forcing residents to ration water as assessments of the water network continue. 

The earthquake has caused widespread structural damage, with many buildings either collapsing or severely damaged, including diplomatic missions. Telecommunication services are largely disrupted, with reliable communication limited to those using Starlink systems.

At Vila Central Hospital, emergency care is being delivered outside the facility due to concerns about the building's structural safety. The hospital's operating theatre is non-functional, and temporary tents have been set up to treat the injured.

Landslides and damage to roads and bridges have restricted access to the airport and seaport. While the seaport remains closed, the airport is operational for incoming humanitarian aid.

contacts.title: Head of Delegation, IFRC CCD for the Pacific

field_reports.description:
A magnitude 7.3 earthquake hit near Port Vila, Vanuatu, on December 17, 2024, at around 12:47 PM local time. The epicenter was approximately 30 kilometers west of Port Vila at a depth of 57 kilometers. Initial reports suggest at least six unconfirmed fatalities and major communication disruptions, which delayed contact with the National Disaster Management Office (NDMO) and government officials until around 6:30 PM local time. Starlink was eventually activated to restore communication with the NDMO.

Communication, electricity, and water outages have significantly impacted the affected areas following the earthquake. Rapid initial response efforts are underway, with communities urgently requesting shelter for evacuees now staying on football fields without protection. Local authorities have emphasized the need for supplies such as drinking water, tarpaulins, medicine, and shelter materials and tools. Internet services remain down in the affected regions, with Starlink being relied upon for communication as telecom providers Vodafone and Digicel work to assess damages and restore their networks. Reports have confirmed six deaths due to a landslide and two people rescued To date 19 death reported and 1/3 of the population is affected. 

Key highlights
•    Magnitude 7.3 earthquake near Port Vila, Vanuatu.
•    Occurred on December 17, 2024, at 12:47 PM local time.
•    Epicentre 30 km west of Port Vila at a depth of 57 km.
•    At least 6 unconfirmed deaths.
•    Communication, electricity, and water outages reported.
•    Rapid initial response underway.
•    Evacuees are sheltering on football fields without proper protection.
•    Supplies Needed are Drinking water, Tarpaulins, Medicine, Shelter materials and tools.
•    Internet services still down; Star link activated to support communication.
•    Vodafone and Digicel assessing damages to restore networks.
•    6 deaths confirmed from a landslide.
•    2 rescued from a collapsed building.
•    Search ongoing for additional missing individuals.
•    VRCS Emergency Operations Centre (EOC) activated on 17 December 2024.
•    VRCS Staff on standby for response.
•    10 volunteers deployed to Vila Central Hospital Medical Store.
•    Shelter Officer on route around the island for observation and assessment.

The Government of Vanuatu is leading the humanitarian response and all national clusters are actively coordinating and meeting regularly with all the partners. The Cluster system in Vanuatu is a stand-by committee that is also active during preparedness & response. Clusters are led by the relevant Line Ministry or National Disaster Management Office (NDMO) and co-led by agencies. After a disaster, and upon activation of the State of Emergency, the overall coordination of the response lies with the NDMO & the NDC.

VRCS, with the support of IFRC, Core-leads the Shelter Cluster in Vanuatu, supports the NDMO as lead agency, for this response, as well as it does during preparedness. VRCS operation includes all relevant sectors such as Shelter, WASH, Health, Logistics, Gender and Protection, Displacement and Communication and CVA. 
The VRCS staff and volunteers working within each cluster are in continuous liaison and communication with their respective National Cluster groups to ensure information sharing and continuous updates. VRCS Emergency Operations Centre (EOC) was activated on 17 December 2024. 10 volunteers deployed to Vila Central Hospital Medical Store. Shelter Officer en route around the island for observation and assessment.

On December 17, 2024, a powerful magnitude 7.3 earthquake struck near Vanuatu's capital, Port Vila, around 02:25 PM, leaving thousands of people in urgent need of aid. Immediate priorities include life-saving Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH) supplies, first aid, health services, and psychological support. A State of Emergency was declared on December 17, 2024, in the worst-affected areas of Vanuatu for a duration of seven days.

 

By December 18, the National Disaster Management Office (NDMO) confirmed 14 fatalities caused by collapsed buildings and landslides. The death toll could rise as search and rescue operations expand. Over 200 people have been injured, with many still missing. According to UNICEF staff on-site, injuries are primarily fractures, cuts, and trauma caused by falling debris. The Government of Vanuatu (GoV) estimates that over 80,000 people have been affected. Two major water reservoirs in Port Vila are severely damaged, forcing residents to ration water as assessments of the water network continue. 

The earthquake has caused widespread structural damage, with many buildings either collapsing or severely damaged, including diplomatic missions. Telecommunication services are largely disrupted, with reliable communication limited to those using Starlink systems.

At Vila Central Hospital, emergency care is being delivered outside the facility due to concerns about the building's structural safety. The hospital's operating theatre is non-functional, and temporary tents have been set up to treat the injured.

Landslides and damage to roads and bridges have restricted access to the airport and seaport. While the seaport remains closed, the airport is operational for incoming humanitarian aid.

contacts.name: Katie Greenwood
contacts.title: Head of Country Office, CCD Suva

field_reports.description:
Pentecost Island is still faced with numerous road blockages, landslides, and running creeks. Sea level rise, floods, and damaged coastline also contaminated water supplies. People are still in evacuation centers waiting for repairs to their homes. Communication networks are slowly getting back. Digicel Network is now operational in North Pentecost and Vodafone Network will soon to be operational in North Pentecost. In Malampa, many communities are well organized after the cyclone to carry out their first response actions. They are helping other families who are in need, working to quick fix their family shelters, and helping to rebuild or reconstructing new roads to maintain access. In Shefa, communities are prioritizing rebuilding destroyed toilets to ensure good hygiene and reduce pressures to the health system. As per rapid assessment and inputs from the communities, there will be enough food for the next 3 weeks. The economy of the island depends a lot on the market of fresh garden produce and fishing. Seedling of crops and vegetable is needed with immediate response.

There is also the need to supply garden tools such as crowbar, spade iron, knife, chain saw, knife, axes, etc. In all affected provinces, WASH is the major challenge as water supply issues ranging from contaminated sources due to saltwater intrusion to limited supplies because of drought conditions. Many communities need community tanks and water catchment to address clean water issue. This lack of a clean source of water is putting the affected population with increased risks of water borne diseases. Food insecurity in the affected provinces from damaged crops from fields and gardens. Source planting material is a priority activity. Medicines and health assets are limited as road blockages continue to hinder movement.

Relief organizations and governmental agencies continue to make assessments and to distribute relief items to affected communities. As international assistance is arriving, the challenge has been to transport them to people in need. Ships chartered by VRCS, along with other ships used by other organizations and agencies are leaving Port Vila to Pentecost Island and the Paama,Ambryml-Malekula areas respectively. 
The access to clean water is still a major concern as many communities are faced with either inadequate or non-existent supplies. This is most acute in West Gaua, Mere Lava, Merig, East Vanua Lava, Southeast Malekula. Food insecurity now and in the near term are high priorities. Assessment continues also with challenges. Response activities include sharing information to encourage affected communities to commence replanting. Future efforts will involve the distribution of seeds, and rehabilitating livestock and fisheries.

Coordination
The cluster system has been activated in Vanuatu to coordinate the humanitarian response. The humanitarian community works through this national cluster system. Clusters are led by a Line Ministry and co-led by a humanitarian agency. Overall coordination lies with the Vanuatu National Disaster Management Office (NDMO).
To organize an emergency response, Vanuatu's government has convened an inter-agency briefing with officials from the National Disaster Management Authority. The Most affected areas being prioritized areas yellow and Red. VRCS, as co-lead of the Shelter Cluster and Communications Cluster to support government lead agency National Disaster Management Office (NDMO) in the response of TC Lola. 

Operational Strategy
The overall objective of the immediate humanitarian response in the event of an emergency/disasters is to mitigate suffering of the most affected population through provision of Non-Food Items (NFIs) and other relevant interventions. Assessment team has started to conduct rapid technical assessments that will last for 3-4 days in which the VRCS plans to respond to about 6000 households which is equivalent to 20,000 beneficiaries in the affected targeted areas. The operation includes all clusters such as: Shelter, WASH, Health, Logistics, Gender and Protection, Displacement and Communication.

Logistics

VRCS Logistics Team coordinated and communications of NFI transportations and logistics from
warehouse to the affected communities affected.
Assessment teams travel to Pentecost to conduct rapid assessment and the planning of the distribution of relief items at respective islands.
Completed the survey of current stocks on hand and prepared them for shipment to the affected areas.
Mobilize volunteers both at Port Vila headquarters and in the islands of Sanma, Torba, and Penama.
Exploring possibility of arranging separate transport to deliver necessary relief items and volunteers to the affected areas.
Moving stocks from warehouses to docks for loading to ship for transit to Malampa and Pentecostal Islands.

contacts.name: Katie Greenwood
contacts.title: Head of Delegation, CCD Pacific office

field_reports.description:
Road closures and communication issues are continuing to hinder relief efforts. While significant progress has been made in restoring essential communication networks, including radio and satellite systems, aiding coordination and information sharing for disaster response and recovery, issues remain in connecting with many parts of Penama and Ambrym Island. Road closures due to blockages and landslides are also preventing relevant government agencies and aid organizations from accessing areas for assessment and distribution. In addition, public road access and feeder roads to gardens are also blocked, affecting food security risks and livelihood. Root crops and 
vegetables are partly damaged in North Ambrym communities and 939 households will face food shortages in one to two weeks. Crops from gardens are decaying due to the impact of salt spray on farmlands in East Vanua Lava. All gardens have been severely destroyed, and households would face shortage of food in less than a week in East Gaua & Mere Lava.In many parts of North Ambrym and Pentecost Island, safe water is a critical issue. Water storage tanks are contaminated with green leaves causing the water to turn green and black and saltwater intrusions to underground wells in other are also creating access to clean water. This shortage comes at a time of drought in many of the affected areas

contacts.name: Katie Greenwood
contacts.title: Head of Delegation, CCD Pacific office

field_reports.description:
Assessments and distributions have started and continues with the help of local volunteers and Emergency Response Teams members. Conditions still remain to be challenging with landslides affecting entire communities in Shefa Province and road blockages in Torba. Communications remain unstable and on many islands. Water sources, exacerbated by drought from post El NiÅ„o conditions are also damage by storm surge and access to clean water for residents on Ambrym Island and Penama are greatly affected. Gardens are severely damaged in Torba and Malampa.
In addition, there have been outbreaks of conjunctivitis, diarrhea, and malaria being reported in North Pentecost and Malampa. Preliminary assessments from NDMO personnel have been coming with reports in local provincial and local area councils.Local officials have reported an urgent need for road clearing as well as supplies such as drinking water, 
tarpaulins, medicine, and shelter materials and tools

Preliminary assessments from NDMO personnel have been coming with reports in local provincial and local area councils. Information from NDMO indicates that traditional thatch houses sustained significant damage along with other structures that weren't cyclone-proof. Several islands within the provinces of Torba, Malampa, and Penama experienced major damages to gardens and homes and other agricultural areas which will affect food security. There are reports of contaminated water sources. The Santo Grid managed without interruptions yet communications to the Ambae grids and Talise in Maewo remain offline. As a precautionary measure, the Talise Hydro was shut down Friday. This also included the Saratamata and Lolowai grids. Local officials have reported an urgent need for road clearing as well as supplies such as drinking water, tarpaulins, medicine, and shelter materials and tools. Telecommunications in the impacted areas were still down, and officials and other reacting groups are relying on Star Link to communicate. Vodafone and Digicel have assessed the damage and are in the process of repairing their respective network

A new tropical cyclone named LOLA formed over the South Pacific Ocean on 21 October and started moving south toward Vanuatu, strengthening. The Vanuatu Meteorology Department upgraded the cyclone to category 5 on Tuesday morning (October 24th), with the slow-moving storm hovering over the north of the country, about 250km northeast of the capital Port Vila. It estimates winds of up to 215kph at the centre of the storm, with "destructive hurricane force" winds of up to 165 kph expected to hit multiple provinces in the country's north and central provinces, specifically Toba, Sanma, Penma, Malayampa, and Shefa. It is estimated that approximately 150,000 people (30,000 Households) will be affected. 

Vanuatu Red Cross
The Vanuatu Red Cross Society (VRCS) has commenced early warning activities in Toba, Sanma, Penma, Malayampa, and Shefa. The VRCS is working together with the National Disaster Management Office (NDMO) to prepare for post-landfall assessments and response coordination. The VRCS branches are additionally coordinating at the provincial level with the Provincial Operation Centres (POCâ€™s) to prepare for assessment and response planning at the field level. All Shelter activities will be guided by the NDMO together with the VRCS as they are co-leads of the National Shelter Cluster. Priority needs are anticipated to be WASH, Shelter, Health, MHPSS, and First Aid. Currently, the VRCS has in-country stocks capable of assisting 1000 families. The VRCS is the co-lead together with the NDMO for the National Shelter Cluster.
The Vanuatu government has requested International Assistance and a DREF Operation is planned to be launched.


â€ƒ
A new tropical cyclone named LOLA formed over the South Pacific Ocean on 21 October and started moving south toward Vanuatu, strengthening. The Vanuatu Meteorology Department upgraded the cyclone to category 5 on Tuesday morning (October 24th), with the slow-moving storm hovering over the north of the country, about 250km northeast of the capital Port Vila. It estimates winds of up to 215kph at the centre of the storm, with "destructive hurricane force" winds of up to 165 kph expected to hit multiple provinces in the country's north and central provinces, specifically Toba, Sanma, Penma, Malayampa, and Shefa. It is estimated that approximately 150,000 people (30,000 Households) will be affected. 

Vanuatu Red Cross
The Vanuatu Red Cross Society (VRCS) has commenced with early warning activities in Torba Province, Penama Province, Sanma Province Malampa Province and Shefa Province. The VRCS is working together with the National Disaster Management Office (NDMO) to prepare for post-landfall assessments and response coordination. The VRCS branches are additionally coordinating at the provincial level with the Provincial Operation Centres (POCâ€™s) to prepare for assessment and response planning at the field level. All Shelter activities will be guided by the NDMO together with the VRCS as they are co-leads of the National Shelter Cluster. Priority needs are anticipated to be WASH, Shelter, Health, MHPSS, PGI, ECV, MHM, Hygiene Promotion, PFA, CBHFA and First Aid. Currently, the VRCS has in-country stocks capable of assisting 1,000 families. The VRCS is the co-lead together with the NDMO for the National Shelter Cluster.
The Vanuatu government has requested International Assistance and a DREF Operation is planned to be launched.

field_reports.description:
Rapid Assessment Teams was deployed today, 9 March 2023 to rromango and Futuna to support and assit the Area Council and the Community Disaster Climate Committees (CDCCCs) with the rapid assessment.

For cluster updates please refer to the link below :

https://reliefweb.int/report/vanuatu/government-republic-vanuatu-national-disaster-management-office-neoc-situation-report-11-tc-judytc-kevin-9-march-2023

On midnight 27 Feb 2023, Tropical Dression 08F was located about 190km west of Rotuma as it headed southwest towards Vanuatu. At about 12pm 27 Feb 2023, the tropical depression has formed into a tropical cyclone in the Regional Specialized Meteorological Centre (RSMC)- Nadi's area of responsibility (AoR) near Solomon Islands and named Tropical Cyclone (TC) Judy Category 1.

TC Judy moved fast southwest direction and tracked over the small islands int he souithern part of Solomon islands as Category 1 system on 27 Feb 2023 and approached the northern pats of Vanuatu midday 28 Feb 2023 as a Category 2 Cyclone. On 28 Feb 2023, TC Judy has intensified further into Category 3 and to Category 4 as it pased over Shefa Province, where Port VIla, the capital of Vanuatu, is located. TC Judy maintained its strength as it made a landfall in Tanna Island midnight 1 March 2023.

While TC Judy was moving in a south-southeast direction away from the Vanuatu group in past midnight 2 March 2023, another tropical low that was formed in Coral Sea was entering Vanuatu Area of Responsibility (AoR) as a Tropical Cyclone Category 1 system named Kevin. The TC Kevin strengthened to Category 3 and Category 4 system as it moved across central and southern provinces. TC Kevin made landfalll in Tanna Island on 4 March 2023.

Destructive hurricane force winds of 150kph, peak gusting to 220kph affected the central and southern islands. Damaging gale force winds of 63*87kph were over the provinces of Penama, Malampa, Shefa and Tafea. Heavy rainfalls and thunderstorm affected central, southern and parts of the northern islands with seas became very rough with heavy swells over Vanuatu waters.

Air Vanuatu cancelled all domestic and international flights on 28 Fen and 1 March with flights expected to resume on 2 March 2023. Banks were closed on 1-2 March, including schools and other bsinesses. Despite VRCS offices were closed during the days TC Judy and TC Kevin passed over the groups to allow staff members to prepare for the impact of the cyclone. DM and EOC team were on standby for response.
field_reports.summary: VUT: Cyclone - 2023-02 - Cyclone Judy and Kevin

field_reports.description:
On midnight 27 Feb 2023, Tropical Depression 08F was located about 190km west of Rotuma as it headed southwest towards Vanuatu. At about 12pm 27 Feb 2023, the tropical depression has formed into a tropical cyclone in the Regional Specialized Meteorological Centre (RSMC) – Nadi’s area of responsibility (AoR) near Solomon Islands and named Tropical Cyclone (TC) Judy. TC Judy intensify and developed to Category 4 on 1 March.

While TC Judy Category 4 was moving in a south-southeast direction away from the Vanuatu group past midnight 2 March 2023, another tropical low that has been forming in Coral Sea was entering Vanuatu Area of Responsibility (AoR) as a Tropical Cyclone Category 1 system named Kevin. TC Kevin has rapidly intensified into Category 2 system and is forecast to affect central and southern provinces and move with similar track path of TC Judy. TC Kevin may gain its strength further into Category 3 and is expected to make a landfall in Tanna Island on 4 Mar 2023.

Damaging gale force winds of 75kph with gusts up to 105kph are expected to affect TORBA and SANMA provinces within the next 24 hours as the system approaches the northern and central provinces. Heavy rainfalls with possible thunderstorms expected over northern Vanuatu with flash flooding in low lying areas, areas close to the riverbanks and including coastal flooding. Seas will become rough to very rough with moderate to heavy swells over northern and central waters of Vanuatu.

Right after severe TC Judy exited the Vanuatu group, authorities and Vanuatu Red Cross Society (VRCS) began to commence assessment to figure out the extent of damage that was caused by TC Judy. As TC Kevin Category 2 is entering and moving across Vanuatu, assessment and clean-up have been hampered and it is still not clear the length or widespread of the damage. As of today, most parts of the capital Port Vila and northern islands are without power, schools and businesses remain closed. On remote islands, phone and internet reception is limited and people without access to cyclone warnings through radio or other means of communications are being alerted to the risks by provincial emergency coordinators.

 

An initial observation of the damage from TC Judy by the NDMO revealed many houses on Epi Island in Shefa Province were destroyed, with some families sheltering under beds and tables in their houses as TC Judy hammered most parts of the northern islands. There is likelihood of massive damage to houses, churches, crops, power lines and also flooding in low-lying areas. The storm uprooted trees and forced evacuations with power outages are reported across the area of the capital city Port-Vila. There is still no confirmed figure as to the extent of damage, it is estimated that more than 50% houses are damaged in rural Efate Island while in urban Port-Vila at least 20% of houses are damaged. Major damage is likely in Shefa and Tafea provinces.
field_reports.summary: VUT: Cyclone - 2023-02 - Tropical Cyclone Development in Vanuatu

results.name: Vanuatu Tropical Cyclone Judy and Kevin 2023
results.summary:
Over 167,000 people are estimated to be affected by TC Judy, andÂ more than 50% houses are damaged in rural Efate Island while in urban Port-Vila at least 20% of houses are damaged. Major damage is likely in Shefa and Tafea provinces. Damage assessment is being put on hold by the government and VRCS as Vanuatu is bracing up for TC Kevin that will cross over central and southern provinces this Friday and Saturday and is forecast to intensify into Category 2 or 3 system before making landfall in Tanna Island.Â Yellow Alert is in effect for Sanma province, while Blue Alert for TorbaÂ and Malampa provinces.

While TC Judy Category 4 was moving in a south-southeast direction away from the Vanuatu group past midnight 2 March 2023, another tropical low that has been forming in Coral Sea was entering Vanuatu Area of Responsibility (AoR) as a Tropical Cyclone Category 1 system named Kevin. TC Kevin has rapidly intensified into Category 2 system and is forecast to affect central and southern provinces and move with similar track path of TC Judy. TC Kevin may gain its strength further into Category 3 and is expected to make a landfall in Tanna Island on 4 Mar 2023.

Damaging gale force winds of 75kphÂ with gusts upÂ toÂ 105kphÂ are expected to affect TORBA and SANMA provinces withinÂ the next 24 hours as the system approaches the northern and centralÂ provinces. Heavy rainfalls with possible thunderstorms expected over northern Vanuatu with flash flooding in low lying areas, areas close to the riverbanks and including coastal flooding. Seas will become rough to very rough with moderate to heavy swells over northern and central waters of Vanuatu.

Right after severe TC Judy exited the Vanuatu group, authorities and Vanuatu Red Cross Society (VRCS) began to commence assessment to figure out the extent of damage that was caused by TC Judy. As TC Kevin Category 2 is entering and moving across Vanuatu, assessment and clean-up have been hampered and it is still not clear the length or widespread of the damage. As of today, most parts of the capital Port Vila and northern islands are without power, schools and businesses remain closed. On remote islands, phone and internet reception is limited and people without access to cyclone warnings through radio or other means of communications are being alerted to the risks by provincial emergency coordinators.

Â 

An initial observation of the damage from TC Judy by the NDMO revealed many houses on Epi Island in Shefa Province were destroyed, with some families sheltering under beds and tables in their houses as TC Judy hammered most parts of the northern islands. There is likelihood of massive damage to houses, churches, crops, power lines and also flooding in low-lying areas. The storm uprooted trees and forced evacuations with power outages are reported across the area of the capital city Port-Vila. There is still no confirmed figure as to the extent of damage, it is estimated that more than 50% houses are damaged in rural Efate Island while in urban Port-Vila at least 20% of houses are damaged. Major damage is likely in Shefa and Tafea provinces.

field_reports.description:
Vanuatu Meteorology and Geo-Hazards Department (VMGD) issued an update on Yasur volcano on 22nd October 2021 that Yasur volcano alert is currently on Level 2 and the activity has intensified in the level of major unrest state. 
The observations on ground indicate that Yasur volcano has emitted massive plumes of volcanic ashes and gas at around 2pm on 22nd October till late in the night. With this massive activity, the danger zone is increased to 1KM around the volcano cone and the danger zone for life safety is moved to danger zone B (See picture below). Some explosions remain intensified and volcanic projectiles or bombs may fall in and around the summit crater. The level of risk for visitors accessing areas from the crater rim to the parking area (Danger Zone A) remains high. With this current level of activity, villages located close to the volcano may continue to expect volcanic gases and/or ash fall impacts, especially those exposed to the wind direction.
Map of Danger ZONE
 

 Tafea Province Government has activated the PDEOC on the 25th Oct 2021 at the PDO conference room. All Government officer and working Partners at the provincial level, have attended the sectorial meeting facilitated and coordinated by the PDO at the PDEOC before the team deployment to the field at 1pm.
The purpose of activating the EOC was to monitor and report on the acid rain that occurred on the 21st of October 2021 followed by the heavy ashfall on the 22nd October 2021 
The heavy rainfall caused the landslide to fall into the crater of the volcano, which triggered the eruption. Heavy ash fall felt towards the South East of the Island. The area is consisted of one Area Council. The South East Tanna Area Council is made up of 14 different tribes and has a total of 30 communities. 
As per Assessment report analysis, the following were considered to be the priority Needs:
-	Water
-	Shelter
-	Food
-	Health Protection
-	Livelihood
